titlestmt.titleproper: Henry Luce Foundation records, Record Group 9, Accession 2019:003
A Guide to the Henry Luce Foundation records, Record Group 9, Accession 2019:003 FA1717

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-11-01 04:58:53 -0400.

did.unittitle: Henry Luce Foundation records, Record Group 9, Accession 2019:003

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. Access copy currently unavailable. Please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Henry Luce Foundation was established by Henry R. Luce in 1936. As a New York-based nonprofit organization, the Luce Foundation awards grants in American Art, Asian studies, Higher Education, Theology, and supports the Clare Boothe Luce Program for women in science, mathematics, and engineering.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by the Henry Luce Foundation in 2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Henry Luce Foundation records (Record Group 9) consists primarily of grant and professorship files. There is also a substantial amount of material regarding the United States-China Cooperative Research program.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC holds legal title. The Henry Luce Foundation retains all applicable intellectual property rights in so far as it holds them.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Henry Luce Foundation records (Record Group 9) are arranged as follows:
Series 3: United States-China Cooperative Research Program, 1988-2010

United States-China Cooperative Research Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The United States-China Cooperative Research Program was initiated in 1998. It's aim was to encourage sustained joint research by American and Chinese scholars on significant topics in the humanities and social sciences to improve understanding of China and US-China relations. The cooperative research projects typically involved two or more collaborators on both the Chinese and American sides, working together over a three-year period.
